turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Hull speed.
turn.1: What is meant by hull speed?
turn.2: Hull speed Hull speed or displacement speed is the speed at which the wavelength of a vessel's bow wave is equal to the waterline length of the vessel.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: As boat speed increases from rest, the wavelength of the bow wave increases, and usually its crest-to-trough dimension (height) increases as well.
turn.5: What happens if the speed is exceeded?
turn.6: When hull speed is exceeded, a vessel in displacement mode will appear to be climbing up the back of its bow wave.
turn.7: What happens to the vessel then?
turn.8: From a technical perspective, at hull speed the bow and stern waves interfere constructively, creating relatively large waves, and thus a relatively large value of wave drag.
turn.9: Is there anything else of note about hull speed?
turn.10: Though the term "hull speed" seems to suggest that it is some sort of "speed limit" for a boat, in fact drag for a displacement hull increases smoothly and at an increasing rate with speed as hull speed is approached and exceeded, often with no noticeable inflection at hull speed.
turn.11: What are some other important aspects of it?
turn.12: The concept of hull speed is not used in modern naval architecture, where considerations of speed/length ratio or Froude number are considered more helpful.
